entity1.name: Bread
entity1.description: The chemical process by which substances undergo anaerobic glycolysis and produce energy, often resulting in the production of alcohol or acids.;;;A technique used in baking to mix and develop the dough, which helps to form gluten strands.;;;A type of fungus that plays a key role in various biological processes, including fermentation.;;;A staple food prepared from a dough of flour and water, usually baked. It is one of the oldest and most widely consumed foods in human history.;;;A staple food made from dough that has been baked, often leavened with yeast or another agent to create an airy texture.;;;A microorganism that is commonly used in baking and brewing to produce carbon dioxide and alcohol through fermentation.;;;Components or elements used in the preparation of food, such as flour, water, yeast, and salt, which are mixed to form dough for bread baking.;;;A microorganism used in baking and brewing to produce carbon dioxide, which helps dough rise.;;;A culinary technique involving the preparation of dough and its transformation into bread through heat application.;;;A thick, malleable mixture of flour and other ingredients used in cooking, particularly as the base for baked goods like bread.;;;The process of cooking bread using dry heat, typically in an oven, which transforms the dough into a finished product.;;;A mixture of flour, water, and often other ingredients such as yeast or salt, used in baking to make bread, pastries, and other baked goods.;;;A staple food prepared from a dough of flour and water, usually baked.;;;A chemical reaction that causes the surface of bread to turn brown during baking.;;;The process of cooking food using prolonged dry heat, usually in an oven, which causes chemical changes that affect the flavor and texture of the food.;;;A powder obtained by grinding grain, used to make bread, cakes, and pasta.;;;A mixture of flour and water, often with yeast or other leavening agents, that is kneaded into a mass before being baked.;;;A method used in baking to mix and develop the dough by repeatedly folding, stretching, and pressing it.;;;A fine powder made from grinding grains, seeds, or roots, commonly used in baking.;;;A microorganism that is commonly used in baking and brewing to produce carbon dioxide gas, which helps bread rise.;;;A thick, malleable mixture of flour and water, often with other ingredients such as yeast, salt, and oil, used to make bread, pastries, and other baked goods.;;;A type of bread made using traditional methods, often with a focus on quality and flavor over mass production.;;;A single-celled microorganism that is commonly used in baking and brewing to produce carbon dioxide and alcohol through the process of fermentation.;;;A powder made by grinding raw grains or roots and used to make bread, cakes, and other food items.;;;A biochemical reaction where microorganisms convert sugar to acids, gases, or alcohol.;;;A microorganism used in baking and brewing to produce fermentation, which helps bread rise and gives it a light texture.;;;A technique used in baking to mix and develop the dough, ensuring a good texture and rise.;;;The method of preparing food by dry heat, usually in an oven.;;;The technique of cooking food by dry heat, typically in an oven, which can cause various chemical reactions including the Maillard reaction.;;;A microorganism that is commonly used in baking and brewing for its ability to ferment sugars and produce carbon dioxide.;;;A thick, malleable mixture of flour, water, and other ingredients that is kneaded or mixed before being baked into bread, pastries, or other food items.;;;A metabolic process that converts sugar to acids, gases, or alcohol. In bread baking, it is crucial for developing the flavor and texture of the bread.;;;The process of preparing and cooking dough to create bread, involving ingredients like flour, water, yeast, and salt.;;;A mixture of flour, water, and other ingredients that is kneaded into a mass and then baked to make bread or pastries.;;;A mixture of flour and other ingredients used in baking before it is cooked.;;;A powder made by grinding raw grains or seeds, commonly used as a base ingredient in bread making.;;;A staple food in many cultures, made from flour and water, usually leavened with yeast or a sourdough starter.;;;A powder made by grinding raw grains or roots, commonly used in baking to make breads and pastries.;;;A fine powder made from grains, seeds, or roots that is a staple in many cuisines.;;;A microorganism that is commonly used in the fermentation process to produce alcohol and carbon dioxide.

entity4.name: water
entity4.description: A chemical substance that is composed of hydrogen and oxygen atoms, essential for the survival of most known forms of life.;;;A transparent and nearly colorless chemical compound that is the most abundant substance on Earth's surface.;;;A clear, colorless, odorless, and tasteless liquid that is essential for most plant and animal life and is the most widely used solvent in industrial and domestic use.
entity4.chunkid: The Science of Baking Bread6;;;The Science of Baking Bread2;;;The Science of Baking Bread13

entity6.name: salt
entity6.description: A mineral composed primarily of sodium chloride that is essential for life and used as a flavor enhancer in cooking.

entity11.name: Fungus
entity11.description: A kingdom of eukaryotic organisms that includes mushrooms, yeasts, and molds.

entity15.name: carbon dioxide gas
entity15.description: A colorless, odorless gas that is a byproduct of many biological processes and industrial activities.;;;A colorless, odorless gas produced by yeast during fermentation, contributing to the leavening of baked goods.;;;A colorless, odorless gas that is a byproduct of cellular respiration and fermentation processes, often used in carbonated beverages and as a greenhouse gas.
entity15.chunkid: The Science of Baking Bread6;;;The Science of Baking Bread13;;;The Science of Baking Bread19

entity19.name: alcohol
entity19.description: An organic compound that is the result of fermentation and can contribute to flavor in certain foods like bread.

entity23.name: fermentation time
entity23.description: The period during which dough is allowed to rise through the action of yeast or other microorganisms, contributing to the development of flavors and textures in bread.

entity27.name: Gluten
entity27.description: A group of proteins found in wheat and other grains, which gives dough its elastic properties and contributes to the texture of baked goods.;;;Large biomolecules or macromolecules consisting of one or more long chains of amino acid residues, which are essential for the structure and function of all living organisms.;;;A protein found in wheat and other grains that gives elasticity to dough and helps it rise and keep its shape.;;;A family of proteins found in wheat and related grains, which gives elasticity to dough and allows it to rise when baked.;;;A protein found in wheat and other grains that gives elasticity to dough and a chewy texture to baked goods.;;;A group of proteins found in wheat and other grains that give dough its elastic properties.
entity27.chunkid: The Science of Baking Bread15;;;The Science of Baking Bread14;;;The Science of Baking Bread28;;;The Science of Baking Bread13;;;The Science of Baking Bread23;;;The Science of Baking Bread12

entity44.name: Heat
entity44.description: The form of energy that is transferred from one body to another as a result of a difference in temperature, playing a crucial role in the baking process.

entity49.name: starches
entity49.description: A carbohydrate that is a major component of many plant-based foods, including flour.

entity52.name: Maillard reaction
entity52.description: A chemical reaction between amino acids and reducing sugars that usually occurs when food is baked, toasted, or seared, leading to the formation of new flavor compounds.;;;A chemical reaction between amino acids and reducing sugars that occurs during the heating, roasting, or baking of food, contributing to flavor and color development.
entity52.chunkid: The Science of Baking Bread23;;;The Science of Baking Bread21

entity55.name: development of complex flavors
entity55.description: The process by which various chemical reactions create a diverse range of tastes in baked bread.

entity58.name: sugars
entity58.description: Simple carbohydrates that serve as an energy source in living organisms. They can be monosaccharides, disaccharides, or oligosaccharides.

entity61.name: oven
entity61.description: A kitchen appliance used for baking and cooking food, typically by using dry heat.;;;A kitchen appliance used for baking and cooking food.;;;A kitchen appliance used for baking, roasting, and heating food.
entity61.chunkid: The Science of Baking Bread26;;;The Science of Baking Bread25;;;The Science of Baking Bread24

entity65.name: Humidity
entity65.description: A measure of the amount of water vapor present in the air.

entity67.name: Crisp Crust
entity67.description: The outer layer of baked goods that is hard and dry to the touch.

entity68.name: Moist Interior
entity68.description: The inner part of baked goods that retains moisture and softness.

entity73.name: people around the world
entity73.description: A collective term referring to all human beings living in various parts of the globe.
